articles.headline: How Happy Are You? A Census Wants to Know
articles.snippet: Officials in a Boston suburb want to promote policies that produce more than just material well-being.
articles.abstract: Officials in a Boston suburb want to promote policies that produce more than just material well-being.
articles.lead_paragraph: SOMERVILLE, Mass. — When they filled out the city’s census forms this spring, the people of Somerville got a new question. On a scale of 1 to 10, they were asked, “How happy do you feel right now?”

articles.headline: Costly Afghanistan Road Project Is Marred by Unsavory Alliances
articles.snippet: The corruption surrounding a major American-financed highway has become another example of sinkholes in Afghanistan for the money of American taxpayers.
articles.abstract: The corruption surrounding a major American-financed highway has become another example of sinkholes in Afghanistan for the money of American taxpayers.
articles.lead_paragraph: GARDEZ, Afghanistan — When construction crews faced attacks while working on a major American-financed highway here in southeastern Afghanistan, Western contractors turned to a powerful local figure named simply Arafat, who was suspected to have links to Afghanistan’s insurgents.
articles.byline: By Alissa J. Rubin and James Risen

articles.headline: Shell Tries to Calm Fears on Drilling in Alaska
articles.snippet: The Obama administration is under pressure as it weighs whether to allow Shell to drill in the Arctic.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration is under pressure as it weighs whether to allow Shell to drill in the Arctic.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAVOONGA, Alaska — Shell Oil will present an ambitious proposal to the federal government this week, seeking permission to drill up to 10 exploratory oil wells beneath Alaska’s frigid Arctic waters.

articles.headline: Many Japanese Factories Recover After Quake
articles.snippet: Ricoh, a maker of copiers, swung into action after the March earthquake and has nearly recovered. Japan says 64 percent of damaged factories have bounced back.
articles.abstract: Ricoh, a maker of copiers, swung into action after the March earthquake and has nearly recovered. Japan says 64 percent of damaged factories have bounced back.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHIBATA-MACHI, Japan — When the ground shook violently on the afternoon of March 11, the ceiling collapsed in part of the huge Ricoh copier factory here, exposing the vents and wires above.

articles.headline: NBC Expected to Pick Curry as ‘Today’ Co-Host
articles.snippet: Ms. Curry is known and liked by viewers, but making any change to the cast of “Today,” the most profitable television news program, carries some risk.
articles.abstract: Ms. Curry is known and liked by viewers, but making any change to the cast of “Today,” the most profitable television news program, carries some risk.
articles.lead_paragraph: NBC is about to shuffle the deck of the most profitable news program on television.
articles.byline: By Bill Carter and Brian Stelter

articles.headline: Keyboards First. Then Grenades.
articles.snippet: Officials want the military to use technologies like smartphones, video games and virtual worlds.
articles.abstract: Officials want the military to use technologies like smartphones, video games and virtual worlds.
articles.lead_paragraph: ORLANDO — Brig. Gen. Harold J. Greene only has to look around his house to realize the challenges the Army faces in engaging young soldiers. His children, he says, are always “buried in a cellphone or an iPad.”
articles.byline: By Andrew Martin and Thomas Lin

articles.headline: Retooled Car Series Revives Summer Box Office Hopes
articles.snippet: “Fast Five” rocked Hollywood by selling almost $84 million in tickets, by far the biggest opening of the year.
articles.abstract: “Fast Five” rocked Hollywood by selling almost $84 million in tickets, by far the biggest opening of the year.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — A maxim of the movie business is that worn-out film franchises cannot be rehabilitated on the side of the road. Once sequel fatigue sets in, they have to be towed into the shop and sold for scrap or fully retooled.

articles.headline: Bin Laden Is Dead, Obama Says
articles.snippet: President Obama said Osama bin Laden had been killed in a firefight during a “targeted operation” that Mr. Obama ordered in Pakistan. He was later buried at sea.
articles.abstract: President Obama said Osama bin Laden had been killed in a firefight during a “targeted operation” that Mr. Obama ordered in Pakistan. He was later buried at sea.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Osama bin Laden, the mastermind of the most devastating attack on American soil in modern times and the most hunted man in the world, was killed in a firefight with United States forces in Pakistan, President Obama announced on Sunday.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker, Helene Cooper and Mark Mazzetti

articles.headline: With Silver Soaring, Attics Give Up Small Fortunes
articles.snippet: With gold and now silver prices high, consumers are unearthing ancient stashes to sell or pawn.
articles.abstract: With gold and now silver prices high, consumers are unearthing ancient stashes to sell or pawn.
articles.lead_paragraph: Finally, that great-aunt’s tarnished tea service can be put to use — no polishing needed.

articles.headline: President’s Vow Fulfilled
articles.snippet: The announcement delivered a victory for a president whose foreign policy has been criticized by his rivals.
articles.abstract: The announcement delivered a victory for a president whose foreign policy has been criticized by his rivals.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- President Obama’s announcement late Sunday that Osama bin Laden had been killed delivered not only a long-awaited prize to the United States, but also a significant victory for Mr. Obama, whose foreign policy has been the subject of persistent criticism by his rivals.

articles.headline: Amid Skepticism, Pakistan Calculates Its Response
articles.snippet: The killing seems certain to further inflame tensions with the United States and raise questions about whether the Pakistani spy agency knew of Bin Laden’s whereabouts.
articles.abstract: The killing seems certain to further inflame tensions with the United States and raise questions about whether the Pakistani spy agency knew of Bin Laden’s whereabouts.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The discovery of Osama bin Laden by American commandos close to the Pakistani capital dealt a devastating blow to the Pakistani military and its intelligence service and set off a fevered round of speculation about how Bin Laden could have been hiding virtually under their noses in a small city that housed military garrisons.
articles.byline: By Carlotta Gall and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: 2 Years After Bankruptcy, Chrysler Posts a Profit
articles.snippet: Chrysler, the only Detroit automaker to lose money last year, earned $116 million in the quarter as it sold more cars at higher prices.
articles.abstract: Chrysler, the only Detroit automaker to lose money last year, earned $116 million in the quarter as it sold more cars at higher prices.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — The Chrysler Group, two years removed from its descent into bankruptcy, posted on Monday its first quarterly profit since 2006, as the company sold more cars and trucks at higher prices.

articles.headline: In Arab World, Bin Laden’s Confused Legacy
articles.snippet: A man who once vowed to liberate the Arab world was reduced to a footnote in the revolutions and uprisings remaking a region.
articles.abstract: A man who once vowed to liberate the Arab world was reduced to a footnote in the revolutions and uprisings remaking a region.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The words were not uncommon in angry Arab capitals a decade ago. Osama bin Laden was hero, sheik, even leader to some. After his death Monday, a man who once vowed to liberate the Arab world was reduced to a footnote in the revolutions and uprisings remaking a region that he and his men had struggled to understand.
articles.byline: By Anthony Shadid and David D. Kirkpatrick

articles.headline: Army Corps Blows Up Missouri Levee
articles.snippet: With the Ohio River rising, officials blew a gap in a levee, sending 550,000 cubic feet of water a second across 130,000 acres of farmland to try to save one Illinois town from flooding.
articles.abstract: With the Ohio River rising, officials blew a gap in a levee, sending 550,000 cubic feet of water a second across 130,000 acres of farmland to try to save one Illinois town from flooding.
articles.lead_paragraph: EAST PRAIRIE, Mo. — Ruben Bennett, his back bent and his fingers gnarled from a lifetime of labor, has lived all of his 88 years on an expanse of rich farmland here, just below where the Ohio River pours into the Mississippi. He survived his share of floods — including the record-setting one that swept away his boyhood home — but he has never run from one, until now.
